Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Flexible Resource Allocation and Efficient Coding in Human Vision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Imagine you are driving in the middle lane of a busy three-lane highway, approaching your exit, with the radio on so you can hear the weather report, and with your children in the backseat calling for you. How are you going to manage this situation? Will you ignore all but one thing, and pay full attention to the road signs to determine when to switch lanes, or to cars in the rearview mirror as you change lanes, or to the radio, or to your children? Or will you somehow divide your attention between all of these incoming streams of information? What is the optimal thing to do under these circumstances, and can you do it? With the support of an NSF CAREER award, Dr. George Alvarez at Harvard University will examine whether people can optimize the way they divide their attention, and how this affects their ability to see and accurately report information in their field of view. We are limited in our ability to attend to multiple things at once, and given the limits on our attention, there is an optimal strategy for how to pay attention in any given situation. This optimal strategy could involve flexibly distributing attention (e.g., paying 40% to the road signs, 40% to cars in other lanes, and 20% to the children in the backseat), or using clever strategies for combing information (e.g., you can get the gist of whether the chatter in the backseat requires your immediate attention without paying attention to each individual voice). The proposed research will examine whether, and how, these different strategies are employed to optimize the use of our limited attentional resources.

A basic level understanding of how people optimize the use of their limited attentional resources opens the door to studying the extent to which attention deficits in humans are due to sub-optimal use of available resources. Thus, the results of the research will have implications for disorders such as Attention Deficit Disorder, Obsessive Compulsive Disorder, Autism, Schizophrenia, Dementia, or disorders due to stroke or brain damage, such as Visual Neglect or Executive Dysfunction. In addition, Dr. Alvarez will use the research project as an opportunity to mentor a cadre of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups. Dr. Alvarez helps coordinate a summer research program that places students in labs, providing them with hands on training in conducting behavioral research. As a professor of Hispanic background, Dr. Alvarez is in a unique position to increase minority representation and visibility in the brain and cognitive sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synopsis

It is well established that humans have a severely limited capacity to pay attention: we can only attend to and keep track of a handful of objects at any given moment. Yet, for the most part, we are capable of performing complicated visual tasks with seemingly little effort. But how do we overcome our capacity limitations to successfully navigate the world? In a series of studies, we have established that the visual system does what any scientist might do: it takes multiple measurements and combines them to represent a “statistical summary” of what was seen (e.g., the average size of objects in a scene). Thus, even when people are unable to report the specific details of a scene, they are often able to describe (or notice changes to) the “statistical gist” of the scene.

Intellectual Merit

Our research led to key insights into how the visual system computes ensemble statistics, and the consequences of those computations on visual perception and cognition, culminating in 15 publications in peer reviewed journals. While previous work had shown that people are able to report statistical properties, such as the average orientation of a set of lines, it was unknown whether the visual system has mechanisms dedicated to computing such summary statistics. In vision science, adaptation methods have been an essential tool for understanding the nature of visual processing. For example, if you stare at a red dot for 20 seconds (the adapting stimulus), and then look at a white screen, you'll see a green dot (the afterimage). Why do you see a green afterimage, and not a blue or purple afterimage? Why do you see an afterimage at all? It turns out the afterimage depends systematically on the adapting image (e.g., if you adapt to yellow, you will see a blue afterimage), and thus we can learn about how visual information is coded from these aftereffects. Such adaptation methods have been used to study how individual objects are represented, but not to understand the nature of ensemble representation. Our studies show that the human visual system adapts to “average orientation” above and beyond what one would predict from adaptation to individual elements. This suggests that there are units in the human visual system that extract and represent statistical properties.

To summarize the overall contribution of our work, our studies have shown that representing “statistical summaries” or “ensembles” is a core computation of the human visual system, relying on dedicated “statistical analyzers” have the hallmark properties of receptive fields in the human visual system. We’ve also provided a computational framework for understanding how the visual system combines information from multiple levels, from individual objects to clusters of objects, to the overall scenes, to give rise to a unified perceptual experience. We’ve also found that this ensemble processing system varies across individuals, and is related to scene perception but not object perception.

Broader Impacts

While the research activities were aimed at obtaining a basic understanding of cognitive and neural function, the project included teaching and mentorship activities that were focused on arming students with general critical thinking and analytical skills that will serve them well in any subsequent career. This included a summer research program which hosted several students per year (2-5 per year), accepted through Harvard University's SROH program (with the Leadership Alliance), the NSF-CELEST funded summer intern program, and Boston University's Summer Study Internship program. Working in the lab provides students with training in all aspects of scientific research, including experimental design and construction, data collection and analysis, data visualization and presentation, and scientific communication in the form of a poster, talk, and research report. All of these skills, particularly data analysis and visualization, along with scientific communication, are general skills that will serve these students in any domain of science, engineering, and technology research. Enhancing these skills will enhance the ability of these students to pursue research and teaching careers in the fields of science, engineering, and technology.

The project has also had a notable impact on the careers of graduate students and postdocs who have contributed to the project, with graduate students moving onto prestigious postdoc positions, and postdocs moving onto the top-choice faculty positions: Graduate student Jordan Suchow is doing postdoctoral research with Tom Griffiths at UC Berkeley; Graduate student Michael Cohen is doing postdoctoral work with Nancy Kanwisher at MIT; Graduate Student Bria Long is in her 6th year of the Harvard PhD program, but has lined up a postdoctoral position with Michael C. Frank at Stanford University; Post-doc Jason Haberman is an assistant professor at Rhodes College (his goal was to become a professor at a small liberal arts college); Post-doc Timothy Brady is an assistant professor at UC San Diego; Post-doc Viola Störmer has also accepted an assistant professor position at UC San Diego.
